item.description: %% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% üìÑ [[_Examinations/Abdominal Exam|Abdominal Exam]] üìÑ [[_Examinations/Cardiovascular examination|Cardiovascular examination]] üìÑ [[_Examinations/Cranial Nerve Exam|Cranial Nerve Exam]] üìÑ [[_Examinations/Respiratory Exam|Respiratory Exam]] üìÑ [[_Examinations/Upper and Lower Limb Neurological Exam|Upper and Lower Limb Neurological Exam]] %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%

Abdominal Exam Tags: #Examination #OSCE #Gastroenterology Introduction Wash hands (and don PPE if needed) Introduce yourself (name and role) Confirm patient’s name and DOB Explain what the examination involves Gain consent to continue Ask if patient in any pain before continuing General inspection Clinical signs Body habitus Scars Cachexia Jaundice Abdominal distension Masses Pallor Objects and equipment Stoma bags - location and type Surgical drains - note location and type/volume of contents Feeding tubes NG or NJ Medical equipment - oxygen, ECG, medications, catheters (note volume and colour), IV access Mobility aids Vital sign charts Fluid balance charts Prescriptions Hands Inspection [[Koilonychia]] & [[leukonychia]] Palmar erythema (redness) Dupuytren’s contracture - thickening of palmar fascia Finger [[Clubbing]] Most likely causes to come up in abdo exam OSCE is [[inflammatory bowel disease]], [[Coeliac Disease]], [[Liver Cirrhosis]] and lymphoma of GI tract

Cardiovascular Exam Tags: #Examination #Cardiovascular #OSCE Introduction Wash hands (and don PPE if needed) Introduce yourself (name and role) Confirm patient’s name and DOB Explain what the examination involves Gain consent to continue Ask if patient in any pain before continuing General inspection Clinical signs Cyanosis Shortness of breath (congestive [[Heart Failure]], [[Pericarditis]], [[pneumonia]], [[pulmonary embolism]]) Pallor - not very sensitive - paleness -> anaemia (haemorrhage, chronic disease) or poor perfusion (congestive [[Heart Failure]]) Malar flush - plum red discolouration of the cheeks associated with [[Mitral stenosis]] Oedema - lots of causes, usually in limbs (pedal) or abdomen (ascites).

Cranial Nerve Exam Tags: #Examination #OSCE Introduction Wash hands (and don PPE if needed) Introduce yourself (name and role) Confirm patient’s name and DOB Explain what the examination involves Gain consent to continue Ask if patient in any pain before continuing Olfactory nerve and glossopharyngeal Have you noticed any change in smell or taste?

Respiratory Exam Tags: #Examination #OSCE #Respiratory Introduction Wash hands (and don PPE if needed) Introduce yourself (name and role) Confirm patient’s name and DOB Explain what the examination involves Gain consent to continue Ask if patient in any pain before continuing General inspection Clinical signs Age - younger [[Cystic Fibrosis]], older [[COPD]], interstitial lung disease or malignancy Cyanosis Shortness of breath Cough - wet: [[pneumonia]], [[bronchiectasis]], [[COPD]], [[Cystic Fibrosis]] dry: [[asthma]], [[interstitial lung disease]] Wheeze/stridor Pallor Oedema Cachexia - malignancy and other end-stage respiratory diseases Objects and equipment Oxygen delivery devices - type & rate Sputum pot Other medical equipment - oxygen, ECG, medications, catheters (note volume and colour), IV access Cigs or vapes Mobility aids Vital sign charts Fluid balance charts Prescription Hands Inspection Colour:¬†cyanosis of the hands may suggest underlying hypoxaemia.

Upper and Lower Limb Neurological Exam Tags: #Examination #OSCE #Incomplete Introduction Wash hands (and don PPE if needed) Introduce yourself (name and role) Confirm patient’s name and DOB Explain what the examination involves Gain consent to continue Ask if patient in any pain before continuing General inspection Clinical signs Watch gait as they walk in/ask them to walk Objects and equipment Medical equipment - oxygen, ECG, medications, catheters (note volume and colour), IV access Mobility aids Pillows - congestive [[heart failure]] patients typically suffer from orthopnoea Vital sign charts Fluid balance charts Prescription Hands Inspection To complete the exam Explain¬†to the patient that the examination is now¬†finished.

%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% üìÑ [[Acute Medicine/RRAPID 1|RRAPID 1]] üìÑ [[Acute Medicine/Sepsis|Sepsis]] %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%

#Acute Recognising and Responding to Acute Patient Illness and Deterioration Life threatening problems must be treated before moving on Regularly reassess Call for help early Airway - can be protected by themselves?
Tags: #Acute Sepsis A life threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection Utilises Quick SODA (qSOFA) scoring system - based on

%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% üìÑ [[Cardiovascular/Acute Coronary Syndrome|Acute Coronary Syndrome]] üìÑ [[Cardiovascular/Angina|Angina]] üìÑ [[Cardiovascular/Aortic Stenosis|Aortic Stenosis]] üìÑ [[Cardiovascular/Atrial Fibrillation|Atrial Fibrillation]] üìÑ [[Cardiovascular/Coronary Artery Disease.
Tags: #Cardiovascular Acute Coronary Syndrome Acute coronary syndrome is¬†a term used to describe a range of conditions associated with sudden, reduced blood flow to the heart.

Tags: #Cardiovascular #Incomplete Angina Pain due to partial blockage of a coronary vessel. Can be stable or unstable stable angina (more common) ‚Äì attacks have a trigger (such as stress or exercise) and stop within a few minutes of resting unstable angina (more serious) ‚Äì attacks are more unpredictable (they may not have a trigger) and can continue despite resting Some people¬†develop unstable angina after having stable angina.

Tags: #Cardiovascular Aortic Stenosis Aortic stenosis - stiffening, narrowing Pressure overload - high resistance low reps -> hypertrophy Causes/Factors Congenital: bicuspid aortic value Calcification of the valve causing narrowing Age 65+ Symptoms [[Angina]] Breathlessness on exercise Pre-syncope/syncope Signs Hard and loud ejection systolic murmur Between S1 and S2 Reduced pulse pressure (difference between systolic and diastolic) Forceful apex beat Diagnostic tests Echocardiogram - left hypertrophy with poor valve movement possible regurgitation ECG - poor R wave progression and stuff which I don’t understand yet Management If pressure difference between ventricle and aorta remains below 60 mmHg the patient is kept under observation
Tags: #Cardiovascular Atrial Fibrillation A rapid irregular atrial rhythm at 300-600 bpm. The AV node blocks most of these impulses and only responds intermittently (hence irregular QRS).

Tags: #Cardiovascular Coronary Artery Disease Coronary artery disease is a narrowing or blockage of your coronary arteries usually caused by the buildup of fatty material called plaque under the endothelium.
Tags: #Cardiovascular #Haematology Deep Vein Thrombosis Where a blood clot forms in a deep vein usually due to pooling of that blood due to lack of movement.
Tags: #Cardiovascular Fallot’s Tetralogy Most common cyanotic congenital heart disorder + most common one that survives to adulthood Tetralogy features:

Tags: #Cardiovascular Heart Block Disrupted passage of electrical impulse through the AVN 1st-degree: prolonged PR interval, unchanging, no missed beats 2nd-degree (Mobitz I): PR interval becomes longer and longer until a QRS is missed.
Tags: #Cardiovascular Heart Failure Defined as when cardiac output is inadequate for the body’s normal requirements. End stage of all cardiac pathologies
Tags: #Symptom Both associated with infective endocarditis Janeway lesion Osler’s nodes
#Cardiovascular #Incomplete

Tags: #Cardiovascular myocardial infarction Belongs to a group of [[Acute Coronary Syndrome]]s along with unstable [[Angina]]. These share a common pathology atherosclerotic plaque rupture, thrombosis and inflammation.

Tags: #Cardiovascular peripheral vascular disease aka Peripheral arterial disease Narrowing, blockage, or spasms in a blood vessel can cause PVD. PVD may affect any blood vessel outside of the heart including the arteries, veins, or lymphatic vessels.
Tags: #Symptom
#Cardiovascular #Incomplete

Tags: #Cardiovascular Ventricular Fibrillation Disorganised chaotic electrical activity and contraction. The heart quivers (fibrillation) and CO falls to ~0 Causes/Factors Little warning of this condition before [[myocardial infarction]] [[Heart Failure]] Symptoms Possible

%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% üìÑ [[Dermatology/erythema nodosum|erythema nodosum]] üìÑ [[Dermatology/Leg Ulcer|Leg Ulcer]] üìÑ [[Dermatology/pyoderma gangrenosum|pyoderma gangrenosum]] %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%
Tags: #Symptom Erythema Nodosum Erythema nodosum is swollen fat under the skin causing bumps and patches that look red or darker than surrounding skin.
Tags: #Dermatology Leg Ulcer Ulcer - loss of area of epidermis and dermis to produce a defect even down to fat, muscle, tendons and bone

Tags: #Dermatology #Incomplete pyoderma gangrenosum Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rare skin condition that causes painful ulcers. It’s usually treatable but can take some time to heal and may leave some scarring.

%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% üìÑ [[Endocrinology/Diabetes Mellitus|Diabetes Mellitus]] üìÑ [[Endocrinology/Grave’s disease|Grave’s disease]] üìÑ [[Endocrinology/Hyperthyroidism|Hyperthyroidism]] %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%

Tags: #Endocrinology Diabetes Mellitus type 1 diabetes¬†‚Äì where¬†the body’s immune system attacks and destroys the cells that produce insulin Latent autoimmune diabetes in adults type 2¬†‚Äì¬†where the body does not produce enough insulin, or the body’s cells do not react to insulin Maturity onset DM of the young (MODY) Gestational diabetes Secondary

Grave’s Disease Tags: #Endocrinology Brief Overview Grave’s disease is an autoimmune disorder and the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. In this condition, the body’s immune system mistakenly attacks the thyroid gland, leading to an excessive production of thyroid hormones.
Hyperthyroidism Tags: #Endocrinology Brief Overview Hyperthyroidism is a medical condition characterized by excessive production of thyroid hormones by the thyroid gland.
%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%

%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/Alcohol-related Liver Disease|Alcohol-related Liver Disease]] üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/Alcoholism|Alcoholism]] üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency|Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency]] üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/Appendisitis|Appendisitis]] üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/Cholecystitis|Cholecystitis]] üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/Coeliac Disease|Coeliac Disease]] üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/Crohn’s Disease|Crohn’s Disease]] üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/Hepatitis|Hepatitis]] üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/Koilonychia|Koilonychia]] üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/leukonychia|leukonychia]] üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/Liver Cirrhosis|Liver Cirrhosis]] üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease|Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease]] üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/Nutritional disorders|Nutritional disorders]] üìÑ [[Gastroenterology/Ulcerative Colitis|Ulcerative Colitis]] %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%

Tags: #Gastroenterology Alcohol-related Liver Disease Alcohol-related liver disease (ARLD) refers to liver damage caused by excess alcohol intake. There are several stages of severity and a range of¬†associated symptoms.

Tags: #Gastroenterology #Neurology #Haematology #Cardiovascular #Reproductive Alcoholism An alcoholic is one whose problematic patter n of alcohol use leads to clinically significant impairment or distress, manifested by multiple psychosocial, behavioural or physiological features.

Tags: #Gastroenterology #Respiratory Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency An inherited disorder affecting lung ([[emphysema]]) and liver ([[Liver Cirrhosis]]). A1AT is a glycoprotein and a serine protease inhibitor made in the liver which controls inflammatory cascades.

Tags: #Surgery #Gastroenterology Appendicitis Most common surgical emergency - highest incidence between 10-20 y/os Causes/Factors Gut organisms invade the appendix wall after lumen obstruction by lymphoid hyperplasia, faecolith or filarial worms

Tags: #Gastroenterology #Surgery Cholecystitis Inflammation of gallbladder Causes/Factors Age Obesity Smoking low fibre intake Symptoms Worsening of pain/symptoms after eating fatty food RUQ Pain Fever/$\uparrow$WCC Jaundice Biliary Colic $\checkmark$ X X Acute cholecystitis $\checkmark$ $\checkmark$ X Cholangitis $\checkmark$ $\checkmark$ $\checkmark$ nausea, vomiting RUQ pain - radiating round side / to back Signs Charcot’s triad - Fever + RUQ pain + Jaundice
Tags: #Gastroenterology Coeliac Disease Coeliac disease is a condition where your immune system attacks your own tissues when you eat gluten.
Tags: #Gastroenterology Crohn’s Disease The inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), [[Ulcerative Colitis]] and Crohn’s disease are chronic autoimmune relapsing and remitting inflammation of the intestine.
Tags: #Gastroenterology Hepatitis Hepatitis is the term used to describe inflammation¬†of the liver. It’s usually¬†the result of¬†a viral infection or liver damage caused by drinking alcohol.
Tags: #Symptom
Tags: #Symptom

Tags: #Gastroenterology Liver Cirrhosis Irreversible scarring of the liver. Disturbed vascular perfusion Causes/Factors [[Alcohol-related Liver Disease]] [[Hepatitis#^b362b5]] [[Wilson’s Disease]] [[Hemochromatosis]] [[Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency]] [[Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease]] Symptoms Portal hypertension - Encephalopathy - Ascites
Tags: #Gastroenterology Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD) The commonest liver disorder in Western industrialised countries. A range of conditions caused by a build up of fat in hepatocytes.

Tags: #Gastroenterology Nutritional disorders Always consider that more than one nutritional disorder is likely to be present Scurvy - lack of vitamin C Look for environmental signs (poor, pregnant, odd diet).

Tags: #Gastroenterology Ulcerative Colitis The inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), ulcerative colitis and [[Crohn’s Disease]] are chronic autoimmune relapsing and remitting inflammation of the intestine.
%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% üìÑ [[Gynecology/Pregnancy|Pregnancy]] %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%

Tags: #Gynecological #Cardiovascular #Gastroenterology #Respiratory #Haematology #Nephrology Pregnancy Pre-existing conditions and non-obstetric disease cause more maternal deaths in the UK than obstetric complications
%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%
%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% üìÑ [[Infectious Diseases/HIV|HIV]] %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%

Tags: #InfectiousDisease Human Immunodeficiency Virus Stages Primary - 2-6 weeks post infection - non-specific illness Secondary - Asymptomatic period Secondary - Symptomatic, immune destruction symptoms begin to appear Late Stage/end stage - AIDs defining

%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% üìÑ [[Nephrology/Acute Kidney Injury|Acute Kidney Injury]] üìÑ [[Nephrology/Chronic Kidney Disease|Chronic Kidney Disease]] üìÑ [[Nephrology/Glomerulonephritis|Glomerulonephritis]] üìÑ [[Nephrology/Minimal change disease|Minimal change disease]] üìÑ [[Nephrology/Nephritic syndrome|Nephritic syndrome]] üìÑ [[Nephrology/Nephrotic syndrome|Nephrotic syndrome]] üìÑ [[Nephrology/Polycystic Kidney Disease|Polycystic Kidney Disease]] üìÑ [[Nephrology/Renal Cell Carcinoma|Renal Cell Carcinoma]] üìÑ [[Nephrology/Tubulointerstitial Nephritis|Tubulointerstitial Nephritis]] üìÑ [[Nephrology/Wilms’ Tumour|Wilms’ Tumour]] %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%

Tags: #Nephrology Acute Kidney Injury Previously known as acute renal failure. Usually doesn’t occur in isolation Stages Stage Creatinine Urine Output 1 SCr increase >26 $\mu$mol/L within 48hr or SCr increase 1.
Tags: #Nephrology Chronic Kidney Disease Abnormalities of kidney function or structure present on at least 2 occasions >3 months apart.
Tags: #Nephrology #Incomplete Glomerulonephritis Immune system attacks glomeruli Causes/Factors Symptoms [[Nephrotic syndrome]] oedema hypoalbuminemia proteinuria >3.5g/day [[Nephritic syndrome]]

Tags: #Nephrology #Incomplete Minimal change disease No change on histology under light microscopy Causes/Factors Child NSAID Symptoms [[Nephrotic syndrome]] normal eGFR Signs Diagnostic tests Management Complications/red flags

Tags: #Nephrology #Incomplete Nephritic syndrome Haematuria in nephritic proteinuria in [[Nephrotic syndrome]] Causes/Factors Symptoms Oedemia mild proteinuria haematuria hypertension renal failure Signs Diagnostic tests Management Complications/red flags
Tags: #Nephrology Nephrotic syndrome Loss of protein in urine GBM has negative charge to repel proteins (Left) Loss of negative charge
Tags: #Nephrology #Incomplete Polycystic Kidney Disease Polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is an inherited condition that causes small fluid-filled sacs called cysts to develop in the kidneys.
Tags: #Nephrology #Oncology Renal Cell Carcinoma Cancer of the kidney that arises from the renal tubular epithelium Two most common:

Tags: #Nephrology #Incomplete Tubulointerstitial Nephritis Type IV hypersensitivity reaction against tubules/interstitium IT IS NOT Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) - direct epithelial damage due to toxins/ischaemia
Tags: #Nephrology #Oncology Wilms’ Tumour Cancer of the kidney that arises from nephroblasts (cells that develop into the kidney in embryological development)
%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% üìÑ [[Neurology/cerebral infarction|cerebral infarction]] %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%

Tags: #Neurology #Cardiovascular Cerebral infarction Two types - ischemia or haemorrhagic Ischemic - clot blocks supply to distal parts of brain to where that clot got lodged Haemorrhagic - bleeding in the brain causing lack of perfusion (plus irritation to that part of brain)
%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%
%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% üìÑ [[Psychiatry/Mental State Exam|Mental State Exam]] %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%
Tags: #Psychiatry Mental State Exam Appearance and behaviour Look at person - description Nervous? Eye contact? Agitated? Playing with hands?
%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%

%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% üìÑ [[Respiratory/asthma|asthma]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/bronchiectasis|bronchiectasis]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/bronchitis|bronchitis]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/clubbing|clubbing]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/COPD|COPD]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/Cystic Fibrosis|Cystic Fibrosis]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/emphysema|emphysema]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/Epiglottitis|Epiglottitis]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/Infectious Mononucleosis|Infectious Mononucleosis]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/Lung Abscess|Lung Abscess]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/Lung Tumours|Lung Tumours]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/Otitis Externa|Otitis Externa]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/Otitis media|Otitis media]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/Pinna Cellulitis|Pinna Cellulitis]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/pneumonia|pneumonia]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/pneumothorax|pneumothorax]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/pulmonary embolism|pulmonary embolism]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/Respiratory Failure|Respiratory Failure]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/Tonsillitis & Pharyngitis|Tonsillitis & Pharyngitis]] üìÑ [[Respiratory/Tuberculosis|Tuberculosis]] %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%

Tags: #Respiratory Asthma Characterised by episodes of dyspnoea, cough, wheeze Reversible airway obstruction and bronchospasm Inflammatory disorder reduces air flow rate Causes/Factors Exact cause of asthma still unknown but autoimmune/mast cell basophil degranulation
Tags: #Respiratory bronchiectasis Chronic inflammation of bronchi and bronchioles leading to permanent dilation and thinning. Easily collapsible - obstructive lung disease

Tags: #Respiratory bronchitis Long-term inflammation of the bronchi. To be classified as chronic bronchitis: You must have a cough and mucus most days for at least 3 months a year, for 2 years in a row.

Tags: #Symptom Clubbing Associated with several underlying disease processes Key respiratory causes - don’t MIS Malignancy - [[Lung Tumours]], [[pleural mesothelioma]] Interstitial lung disease - [[hypersensitivity pneumonitis]], [[interstitial lung disease]] Suppurative lung disease - [[bronchiectasis]],[[Lung Abscess]],[[Empyema]],[[Cystic Fibrosis]]

Tags: #Respiratory COPD Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease A common slowly progressive disorder characterised by airway obstruction Little to no reversibility (how to differentiate from [[asthma]]) Includes chronic [[bronchitis]] and [[emphysema]] Patients usually have either COPD or asthma not both Pink puffers and blue bloaters - likely ends of the spectrum:
Tags: #Respiratory Cystic Fibrosis 1 in 25 people carry the mutation - autosomal recessive. Mutation in CFTR gene on chromosome 7

Tags: #Respiratory emphysema Defined histologically as enlarged air spaces distal to terminal bronchi with destruction of alveoli Over time, the inner walls of the air sacs weaken and rupture ‚Äî creating larger air spaces instead of many small ones

Tags: #Respiratory Epiglottitis Emergency cause of sore throat - life threatening. Notifiable disease Causes/Factors H. influenzae type b the most common cause Other causes include strep pneumoniae and Group A Strep Symptoms Very acute onset Fever Stridor Signs Drooling Muffled voice Diagnostic tests Do not examine the throat of anyone with suspected epiglottitis

Tags: #Respiratory #Incomplete Infectious Mononucleosis Glandular fever Spread through saliva caused almost exclusively from EBV Causes/Factors Symptoms Signs Diagnostic tests Blood sample for EBV VCA IgM and IgG Throat swabs Management Complications/red flags Avoid ampicillin & amoxycillin with EBV as may cause rash

Tags: #Respiratory Lung Abscess A cavitating area of localised suppurative infection within the lung Causes/Factors Inadequately treated [[pneumonia]] Aspiration Bronchial obstruction Pulmonary Infarction Subphrenic or hepatic abscess Clinical Features Swinging fever Productive cough - bad smelling sputum Pleuritic pain Haemoptysis Malaise Weight loss Finger [[clubbing]] Diagnostic tests Bloods - FBC, ESR, CRP, culture Sputum culture CXR: walled cavity often with fluid level Bronchoscopy for specimen Management Antibiotics Drainage

Tags: #Respiratory Lung Tumours Carcinoma of the bronchus - second most common cancer in UK, only 5% cured Causes/Factors Smoking (90%) asbestos chromium arsenic iron oxides radon gas Histology Non small cell lung carcinoma:

Tags: #ENT #Respiratory Otitis Externa Ear canal is the only skin-lined cul-de-sac in the body Acute - symptoms < 3/52 Typically unilateral 90& bacterial, 2% fungal Chronic - symptoms > 3/52 Often bilateral White keratin debris may fill the ear over time Allergic dermatitis to shampoos/cosmetics etc Treat underlying cause Causes/Factors Swimming Trauma Occlusive ear devices Allergic contact dermatitis Dermatological conditions Symptoms Inflammation of the external ear canal presenting with a combination of otalgia, pruritus and non-mucoid ear discharge Signs Diagnostic tests History Otoscopic examination Ear swab or pus sample for culture Management Complications/red flags Pseudomonas bacteria causing a necrotising OE -> life threatening
Tags: #Respiratory #ENT Otitis media Middle ear infection Fluid present in middle ear Very uncommon in children Causes/Factors Viruses Similar bacteria as [[Otitis Externa]] Symptoms Uncomplicated
Tags: #Respiratory #ENT #Incomplete Pinna Cellulitis Associated with trauma (ear piercing & accupuncture) surgery or burns Perichondritis - complicated on high ear piercing

Tags: #Respiratory Pneumonia An acute lower respiratory tract infection associated with fever and other abnormal chest symptoms and signs Causes/Factors Community acquired (CAP) - most common streptococcus pneumoniae.

Tags: #Respiratory pneumothorax Air getting in pleural cavity causing collapse of the lung Becomes a tensions pneumothorax when the pressure causes a shift in the mediastinum -> impairment of cardiopulmonary system
Tags: #Respiratory #Cardiovascular pulmonary embolism Where a clot breaks off and gets lodged in lungs. Most commonly from a [[Deep Vein Thrombosis]]

Tags: #Respiratory Respiratory Failure Type I hypoxia ($PaO_2 < 8kPa$) with a normal or low $PaCO_2$. Its caused primarily by V/Q mismatch, hypoventilation, abnormal diffusion, right to left cardiac shunts.

Tags: #Gastroenterology #ENT #Incomplete Tonsillitis & Pharyngitis Causes/Factors Most commonly caused by viruses - rhino, corona, influenza, adeno Symptoms Sore throat Flu like symptoms Signs Diagnostic tests FeverPAIN Criteria - to determine whether antibiotics might be needed
Tags: #Respiratory #Nephrology #InfectiousDisease Tuberculosis Mycobacterium tuberculosis - can affect almost any organ Infects 1/3 of the world’s population - most common infectious cause of death

%% Zoottelkeeper: Beginning of the autogenerated index file list %% üìÑ [[Rheumatology/Crystal Arthritis|Crystal Arthritis]] üìÑ [[Rheumatology/Inflammatory Arthritis|Inflammatory Arthritis]] üìÑ [[Rheumatology/Osteoarthritis|Osteoarthritis]] üìÑ [[Rheumatology/Systemic Lupus Erythematosus|Systemic Lupus Erythematosus]] %% Zoottelkeeper: End of the autogenerated index file list %%

Tags: #Rheumatology Crystal Arthritis aka Gout Causes/Factors Too much uric acid in blood - kidneys not excreting properly, crystallises out in joints Symptoms Severe pain - can’t bare weight Feet and knee are classic locations Diuretics Give good analgesics Signs Diagnostic tests White toothpaste like fluid removed from the joint with syringe Management Some drug which fixes it in a few months/years
Tags: #Rheumatology Inflammatory Arthritis Usually the lining of the joint that gets affected Anyone at any age can get inflammatory arthritis

Tags: #Rheumatology Osteoarthritis “Wear and tear” - nothing to do from immune system Cartilage flakes off Fragments of cartilage triggers slight inflammatory reaction Bone form cysts as tries to remodel Causes/Factors Age Occupation Athlete (doing something to accelerate wear) Symptoms Inflammation around the joint (in bone and joint) Pain around the joint Weaker muscles (due to lack of use due to pain) Diagnostic tests Clinical examination XR findings Normal CRP and antibodies Does not affect other organs Management Complications/red flags
Tags: #Rheumatology #Cardiovascular #Dermatology #Endocrinology #Gastroenterology #Reproductive #Respiratory #Incomplete Systemic Lupus Erythematosus Anti-DNA reaction so can present in any system

Tags: #Orthopaedics #Surgery #Geriatrics Hip Fractures Fracture of the femur distal to the femoral head and proximal to a level 5 cm below the trochanter

Tags: #Urology #Incomplete Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia Increased number of both stromal and glandular cells in the prostate Causes/Factors Old men Obesity Diabetes FH Clinical Features Lower urinary tract symptoms Diagnostic tests Management Complications/red flags
Tags: #Urology #Incomplete Cryptorchidism aka undescended testis Many babies can be born within the 25-35 week window without testis decent

Tags: #Urology #Neurology Neurogenic Bladder Inability to properly empty the bladder due to neurological damage Two types: Spastic if an upper motor neurone damage Flaccid if damage to peripheral nerves (LMN) Causes/Factors UMN Stroke MS Spinal injury LMN Pregnancy Diabetes Alcohol (B12 deficiency) Symptoms Dysuria Frequency Urgency Abdominal distention Incontinence Diagnostic tests Management Complications/red flags Stasis -> UTI & urinary stones Inability to empty bladder -> hydroureter [[hydronephrosis]]

Tags: #Urology #Incomplete Seminoma Malignant neoplasm of the testis arising form germ cells in the seminiferous tubules Most common type of testicular cancer
Tags: #Urology #Nephrology Urinary Tract Infection Bacteriuria - may be asymptomatic or symptomatic. A diagnosis based on symptoms and signs

Tags: #Urology Urolithiasis Urinary tract calculi/stones Can form anywhere from renal calyx to bladder Types: Calcium (70%) Urate (5%) Cystine (1%) Struvite stones, magnesium ammonium phosphate (staghorn calculi) (15%) Causes/Factors Raised associated mineral

Tags: #Urology #Oncology #Incomplete Urothelial Carcinoma aka transitional cell carcinoma Cancer arising from urothelium accounts for >90% of bladder Causes/Factors Age 60+ Males Exposure to certain industrial chemicals Smoking FH Treatment for other cancers in pelvis - radiation from treatment can cause cancer Clinical Signs Local primary tumour effects Frequency, urgency, dysuria Haematuria Urinary obstruction Effects of distant metastases Lungs Bone Liver Paraneoplastic syndromes Rare
Tags: #Urology Vesicoureteral reflux When urine flows backwards from the bladder to the ureter Affects 10% of population Causes/Factors Age <2 y/o
